title: How to get to grips with the art of Mike Parr
text:
In the Middle Ages people had religion. “Which means nothing to me,” he says. “For me it is almost absurd. But then you had the Black Death, and [religion] was a way to face an existential situation that was essentially unmanageable.

Today’s crisis – climate change and the destruction of the environment – is the same. “I can’t represent the scale of this crisis that is impacting on us," he says. "Because, if it can be represented, it can be possessed and managed psychologically.

“You can only make it fail in a decisive and eloquent and infinitely expandable way.”

Talk of climate change brings up Swedish campaigner Greta Thunberg and her autism. He feels an affinity, he says. His brother, deceased now, was "remarkable as a person, but deeply different".

"He'd sit outside at my place in the mountains for ages, hours sometimes, looking for shooting stars. He became enormously excited, in a very placid sort of way, like he was really fulfilled when he saw something shooting across the sky. That sort of patience I find very moving," he says.

Mike Parr begins his 72-hour entombment at Dark Mofo in June.

In the opening night performance Toward a Black Square – mark 2, Parr will spend seven to eight hours with his eyes closed attempting to paint perfect Malevich black squares, an “unattainable absolute”.

When he performed it in Hobart (as part of MONA's Dark Mofo festival in June), the audience were in a separate room, watching on video screens. “The same elusiveness that’s propelling me, never being able to arrive at this transcendence, is recapitulated in the audience’s experience of the work. They’re not actually there. Experiencing it on video, that delay, all of that constituted the work.”

Self-reflexive loops, recreations and repeats of past works – a certain hall-of-mirrors quality –are features of Parr’s practice. They build the idea that everything he does is part of a single great, ongoing artwork, a claim that irritates McDonald. “This would make it virtually criticism-proof because one cannot hope to see more than a little at a time,” he says.

For Left Field [for Robert Hunter] a life-sized copy of a gallery is being built in Carriageworks' Bay 21. “What happens to the audience is that they walk in this huge gallery and they realise that I’m exhibiting Anna Schwartz’s gallery in Melbourne in her ex-gallery space here in Sydney,” says Parr (Schwartz was based at Carriageworks for eight years).

Advertisement

Playing on repeat will be video of his 2017 opening night at Anna Schwartz Melbourne where he laboriously painted the white walls white. Audio of the event plays over, notably the sound of the crowd, reverential and silent at first but breaking out into chat and conviviality as the night wears on. Does Parr mind that their attention wandered? “There’s something endearing about that,” he says. “It’s the human dimension.”

Left Field is an elegy to a friend, the late Robert Hunter, whom he last saw painting pale canvases in a bright sunroom. The video of Parr painting the walls, poetically filmed by his regular collaborator Gotaro Uematsu, focuses on “diamante edges” of refracted light as Parr applies the wet paint – a memory of something that caught his eye as he watched Hunter work that last time.

Left Field [for Robert Hunter] sees Parr painting the white walls of the Anna Schwartz Gallery white. Zan Wimberley

Parr’s third work, Burning Down The House, captures a previous performance at Carriageworks where he set fire to a pile of his prints, the video also made by Uematsu. A fourth event, a closed performance for which the audience needs to register online to attend, will take place at 1am on November 16.

Audiences often surprise Parr. After Towards a Black Square in Hobart this year he was praised for the “elegant placement” of the dripping, rough-edged patches he had painted in the dark: the aspect that was the least within his control.

After spending 72 hours inside a steel box under a Hobart intersection for MONA’s Dark Mofo Festival in 2018, Parr was struck by the words of an Aboriginal elder: “He said, ‘This is not some kind of Anglo erection of a notable figure in bronze on a plinth. This is an anti-memorial. This is the oblivion. This is the genocide, this is about us.’ So I said, 'Wonderful.'”

So what is Mike Parr, then, if not the controller of this artistic enterprise?

“I’m the person that just … I dispose the signifier. I allocate the signs. I have a clear idea, I think, of what is the potential of the situation, what its potential meanings are. But I think it’s much more important for the audience to discover those meanings.”

The “inevitable random fact at the base of abstract art,” says Parr, is “it truly works when it’s absolutely on the edge of incoherence.

“There is no manual.”

Mike Parr: The Eternal Opening, Carriageworks, 245 Wilson Street, Everleigh, Sydney from October 25-December 8.
description: The 74-year-old's work has been pilloried, puzzled over and applauded for nearly 50 years.
